name: A Philadelphia Experiment
description: The Philadelphia Experiment is some tinfoil conspiracy folklore that the US government tried to teleport a ship from one harbor to another. As the story goes, they actually succeeded, but the result was sailors with their torsos poking out of the floors of the ships, screaming for their lives. ANYWAYS, start hoarding ender pearls, because we're going to be teleporting too! Yaaay! We'll go to strange places, enter machines that break space-time, create new dimensions, and ... store ourselves.

quests.name: Your Ultimate Getaway
quests.description: The Last Millenium is a great place to remember how to spell "millennium" BECAUSE THEY SPELL IT WRONG!!! Beyond that, it is a monster-free, blank space where you are free to build your base in completely lazy comfort. This requires some ender pearls, but is oddly not too resource-intensive. The dyes, however, are unconventional, and you must actively work towards getting all this junk if you want to make the portal. One catch: If you choose to go back to the overworld, it will take you back to the world spawn, not where where you placed the portal.

tasks.longDescription: You need some purple and magenta dyes. Get your mittens on some rose red, bone meal, and lapis lazuli.

Don't forget the ender pearls! Once you make this thing, slap it down somewhere and right-click to enter. You can right-click on a block in the starting spot once you have beamed over to return. Use the chunkloader I give as a reward to keep the area running when you go back to the overworld/whatever to do things.
Time for a field trip! Oh, um, by the way, don't fall off the edge! And also, remember when you return, it's dropping you off at world spawn!

quests.name: Deep Dork
quests.description: The deep dark is a dangerous place that isn't that much better of a place to be in this pack than other places. However, in other packs, it's worth trying. Hell, there is a survival pack that starts you here! You have to know it's very easy to die in it. Darkness actually hurts, and you have to bring tons of torches. The monsters are strong too. Also, there are holes in the world. I am not making it sound appealing, but it's fun to try at least once.

tasks.longDescription: This requires 4 quadruple-compressed cobblestone.

I did not pay too much attention to the quintiuple-compressed cobblestone requirement when I built this the first time. So I got blown sky-high when I tried to make the portal when I did not have one. This thing needs some unstable ingots, so you really need to make sure you have everything straight before you build it.

Finally, the portal. This requires unstable ingots. Again, these will blow you up if you don't handle them quickly enough! You want to set up a crafting table 20-30+ blocks away from your base, get all your stuff arranged together, and do this very quickly! We are talking 10 seconds here!

quests.name: Pearl Diving
quests.description: Ender pearls are pretty obnoxious to get in vanilla Minecraft, and gate the end game part, if you are into that kind of thing. A lot of mods use ender pearls as ingredients. Artifice provides ender ore. It is strange stuff. I cannot tell you exactly where it generates, but I think it has a chance of generating when endermen spawn or teleport underground. I have good luck finding it around Y=12 in lava caves.

tasks.longDescription: Hey, just find it once and I'll feed you a pile of ender pearls.

quests.name: Pearls Before Swine
quests.description: In vanilla Minecraft, there are tall, skinny black aliens called endermen that pop up particularly at night. They don't care about you... unless you look at them. Then they go nuts. They hate water and sunlight and attempt to escape both. They can also teleport all over the place. They drop these green ender pearls when you kill them. You can also make them from ender dust from ender ore thanks to the Artifice mod. If you throw one with a right-click, it will teleport you where it lands. A lot of mods then decided to use ender pearls as a major ingredient of teleportation gear. You had best start stockpiling some.

tasks.longDescription: The easiest way in the early-game to get ender pearls here is through ender ore, or mugging a few endermen if you can hid in a two-block-high murder hole. In the advanced game, you can set up a mob farm to spawn them and autokill them. You'll be swimming in them at that point.

quests.name: Swimming Through Spacetime
quests.description: You can melt down ender pearls into resonant ender. Note that I sometimes refer to it as "fluid ender" because as a memory trick, I learned it was just melted down ender pearls. The stuff isn't hot, or rather there's no really way to tell. Whenever you jump in the stuff, it just beams you somewhere nearby. Fluid ender can be used to cool off a Big Reactor. It is also a component for enderium, which is a very powerful alloy.

tasks.longDescription: **The smeltery cannot smelt ender pearls from lava!**. You can look into hotter fuels like pyrotheum. Better yet, you're become a Big Baby now, so you can try a magma crucible. This will melt just about anything for just a little RF. Then you transfer the fluid ender to a bucket using a fluid transposer. The magma crucible may be kind of rough to make right away.
If you put the machines side-by-side, you can configure the crucible to pump directly into the transposer. Then you don't have to do any plumbing. Get me some of this in a bucket.

quests.name: This Is A Tess
quests.description: The tesseract is an end-game conduit. It transmits across infinite space--including into other dimensions! It has theoretically infinite transfer rates for items, fluids, and power. You should be reaching the point where making these is kind of a casual thing. After this, you will still use conduit in some places to logically organize things, but you'll start using tesseracts for your big stuff. One of the big places to park one is on an import bus into your ME network. You bring another one in your travels and you can unload into your base at any time! However, if you want two different places to communicate with each other, they have to both be within your player's general range, or you have to use chunk loaders to keep the space they're in active!

tasks.longDescription: The parts for a tesseract are generally useless until you reach the end stage, but the device is so powerful that it was warranted necessary to break crafting one into three parts. You will start with a tesseract frame. This will require some serious materials: enderium, a diamond, and some hardened glass. You should have all the equipment to make all this stuff now. Note: You can use a variety of special glasses, but the hardened glass is among the cheapest and easiest to make.
Fill that empty frame with 1,000mb of resonant ender. That may be a full bucket, but it require 4 ender pearls.

We are not done! You have to now encase that filled frame with bronze and silver. Now, when you make the thing, you are not done, because you need at least two of these to get anything out of them! I will give you one! They have to be set to the same channel, and have one has to be receiving where the other is sending if you want anything to move between them.

quests.name: Stating Things Compactly
quests.description: So let's talk about compact machines. This mod let's you create little pocket dimensions inside cubes where you can set up some machines. For example, you could put an entire ore processing rig in one, and just tuck the machine in the corner. It comes with a chunk loader, so stuff happening inside the machine will keep happening even if you leave it automatically. There are a few downsides. One, you have to put this machine exactly where you want it, because everything inside spills out if you move the machine (unless you feed it a nether start... really). Second, It sure does eat up an awful lot of materials to make. I think the big-sized machines are the best bang-for-your-buck. You can run a tree farm inside of one.

tasks.longDescription: Get used to these atom modules. You need six of them each as base ingredients of every compact machine.
The world resizing cube is your common block for all compact machines. You then stud it in other resources to make which tier of machine you want.
Now you stud that machine block in obsidian, and it will make the "big" one.

Not done yet! You need to make a personal shrinking device to actually enter the machine and set up stuff. Once you do, right-click the machine with the shrinking device and it will take you there. You can then use a wrench on the ports on each side to change which side does what. This will let you put things into and take things out of your machine.

quests.name: Construct Additional Pylons
quests.description: Now we get into serious spatial storage. We will ultimately wrap a 16x9x16 volume and pull it out of deep space. You see, we have this strange disk here that contains a portal to ... well, it might be modern myth.

tasks.longDescription: To wrap that volume, you need to rows of pylons completely on two sides, and then a few more to keep the efficiency of the storage solution up. The more pylons you use, the more efficient it gets. This is a big deal. You have to have enough energy to run the storage operation, and that requires AE2's own energy cells. They are not as good as energy storage as other things out there, and they consume fluix to make. However, you can keep doubling your efficiency, which halves the cells you need, until it is manageable. We can frame the 16x9x16 volume using 232 pylons, and 1 dense energy cell. If you make 112 of them, I'll give you another 112. With the 8 you already have, you'll get juuust enough.
This operation gobbles up lots of power. Note, the MORE pylons you use, the LESS energy you need. With 232 pylons, you can clock in at 7.2 million RF.

quests.name: This Drink Takes You Places
quests.description: Getting bored? Want to go on a field trip? Make a plastic cup, and right click it on some resonant ender you have dumped out in the world. Now you have a cup of the stuff. Now... DON'T DRINK IT! Well, not yet! Hehehehe. You need to prepare for a big trip. Drinking that stuff is going to send you upwards of 10 kilometers away in any variety of directions. This is a fun way on a server to start off somewhere new and different from your friends. In this pack, prepare a rattle and make a waypoint in JourneyMap. That way, you can easily send yourself back.

tasks.longDescription: It looks like a flower pot or something as an icon, but this thing is supposed to be like those cheap, red, plastic cups you can probably find in the store to have a college drinking party.
Yeah, so, time to load up the cup. Good luck! Fun fact: If you try to do this in creative mode, it probably won't let you, for whatever reason. Drop into survival mode.

quests.name: You Summoned My Battleship!
quests.description: Admiral Luna thinks this whole thing is some folklore from Baby's First Space Academy, but it's VERY REAL. You have in your possession a spatial drive storing the spatial-compacted ship from the myth. It can be reconstituted in our reality within a spatial storage grid we have been hinting at here. The portal is 16 blocks either way and 9 blocks high, or 16x9x16. That means the spatial frame must be 17x11x17. You want to do this a safe distance from your base because stuff has leaked out of the portal. BE READY FOR WAR! The ship is crewed by mind-warped former sailors, and THEY ARE ARMED. I am not talking "slash slash slash" here. I'm talking "pow pow pow boom" here! We recommend steal armor, an enderium cleaver, a signalum crossbow and enderium bolts, and a few potions.

tasks.longDescription: There are a few items we need from the base. We need some plans for the experiment so we make sure never to do THAT again. The captain probably has that at the front of the ship in the highest room. He probably has a submachinegun. There are some broken orbs just under the deck in the reactor room in the back of the ship. We want one of those to know what happened with them. Finally, there are some keys at the bottom front of the ship in the crew quarters. We're not entirely sure what they unlock, but we can probably figure it out if we get one.

quests.name: Discount Self-Storage
quests.description: Apparently, there are some Buddhist monks that will stuff themselves in a burial chamber, eat nothing but honey for a long time, then mummify themselves before they die for some crazy reason. We're going to do something similarly crazy! Applied Energistics' spatial storage allows you to store yourself! Don't forget to pack a way out! You set up a spatial storage array with an IO port. Toggle that port once you have power and storage--while you are inside of it--and poof! I would recommend not placing the way back until you have stored yourself because some stuff doesn't teleport across space correctly . . . including teleporters. :(

tasks.longDescription: Before you take the trip, prepare a rattle or escape mechanism. If you plan to use a teleporter, place some cobblestone inside the chamber so you can build off of that; the spatial dimension does not like having blocks extended off its boundaries. You need to set up some pylons in three different directions so it knows the region you're beaming up. The pylons should have a cable connecting them all together in one corner; pylons themselves are just little girders themselves that can only go out in one dimension. If you run a pylon into one going another direction, the whole spatial storage region goes down. You know you have it right when you see the purplish color of the pylons turn redder. You can see a demonstration in Baby's First Space City through the teleporter room. USE THE DRIVE I GAVE YOU IN THE LAST QUEST. It contains the proper dimension to complete this quest. Make sure you make a frame that can store a 3x3x3 area. That means the pylons need to encompass a 4x5x4 volume. Oh, and don't place down machines, teleporters, or energy storage. Most of those don't correctly teleport into the new space. Just use regular old blocks. Once you are in the other dimension, you can set up your escape. It's scary! Consider a dry run, and pack your baby rattle! Ohhhh, if you LOST that drive that I gave you in the last quest, then the dimensional salesmen in the stores in Baby's First Space City can help you out... for a price.

quests.name: Living In The Spectrum
quests.description: Safe spaces are all the rage these days. The Random Things mod delivers with the Spectral Dimension. This is a quiet little place only you can personally retreat to in order to build a nice little hiding hole. Combined with compact machines, you get a pretty sweet little hiding place here. I mean, the dimension only gives you a personal 16x16x16 space, but it's an especially great place to stash stuff early in the game. I love this key when I am in "gypsy mode." Sometimes I Just can't find the perfect base, but I can pretty easily make this key and camp somewhere when I need to do some machine stuff. By the way, only you can be inside your own little spectral dimension. If you invite other players in, they'll get whisked out. No griefers for you!

tasks.longDescription: Oddly enough, this will probably be the hardest thing to get. By default, mobs will turn into spirits at a rate of 1% or so. These things zip around arbitrarily and are really hard to nab. But hey, if you do, you get some of this... usually. Apparently the rate improves with different phases of the moon. Also, it doesn't care what kind of mob, so you might set up a little chicken farm just to murder the little buggers for some ectoplasm. Hey! Sometimes to make an omelette you have to break some eggs!

Combine that ectoplasm with some iron and you'll get a spectre iron ingot you can put on a stick. That's your key. Hold down the use button on your mouse (right-click by default) for a little bit and it will whisk you away! Use it again to get sent back. It's reusable, so do not fret.

quests.name: Ender Is Forever
quests.description: Enderium is a serious material. It is used for very advanced, end-game kind of things. For one, tesseracts want them. For another, they are a fantastic Big Reactor turbine coil material; they dramatically outpace electrum and are only beaten by ludicrite, which is a ridiculous material to hunt down. Tools and weapons made from them are also extremely powerful.

tasks.longDescription: Let's talk about the basic ingredients here. This is an alloy made from 4:2:1:1 ender pearls:tin:silver:platinum. Platinum may be called "shiny metal" depending on what you use. The ender pearls come in as a single bucket of resonant ender. For all this effort, you get for resonant ender dusts, which make four ingots.

Put all that dust and the bucket of fluid ender in a crafting grid. Don't double up the tin dust in one cell. Each dust gets a cell. You should be able to make the enderium blend from this. Cooking it down is kind of fancy. We'll get to that.

Now you have to be clever. This stuff won't just cook into ingots, nor will it smelt with the strenght of the lava powering your smeltery. What is a baby to do? Ram the dust through a magma crucible, then inject the molten enderium into a fluid transposer. You can fill a tank up with the stuff; a bucket probably won't work because that needs very specific amounts. The Thermal Expansion tanks especially work. Carry that over to your smeltery. Assuming you have done the obsidian casting in a smeltery quest, you are already tooled for pouring this stuff in. You can cast the fluid enderium in your smeltery. Each dust should yield one ingot. You could skip all this and use an induction smelter with blazing pyrotheum, but the magma crucible->smeltery method does not need those extra materials.

quests.name: Drunk Dialing
quests.description: We established that you use the dimension enscriber to configure new dimensions. We did not specify how. The way to configure a dimension is to arrange "dimlets" inside of the enscriber to describe various aspects of this universe. This follows a specific syntax that I will not delve into here. You see, you can just skip all that and let it come up with something completely crazy! Who knows what you'll get! You might want to be your BFSR rattle to get out in a jiffy if it's really bad! Also, bring a matter transmitter and some power to it. Also, a dialing device as a backup might be smart! You need to be able to beam back home somehow! The new dimension only has a matter receiver to let you in.

tasks.longDescription: You'll need an empty dimension tab that the enscriber can enscribe.

Program the empty tab without any extra dimlets. Just let the escriber knock itself out! You will then have to bring it to the dimension builder and have it build it. You will then have to set up your matter transformer to point to the receiver in the new dimension. Fun fact: The enscriber will create the same random dimension over and over unless you put *some* dimlet in the enscriber. I am giving you digit dimlets so you can make a few random dimensions.

quests.name: Blowing Chunks
quests.description: Let's talk about chunks. They are 16x16 regions in the Minecraft world that is uses to sort and organize world data. If you press F9, you can see where these boundaries are. They go infinitely up and done inside those regions, so the area is the only part that really matters. When chunks generally go out of view by walking away or going to another dimension, everything happening in that chunk just freezes. So if you wanted a huge thing to happen while you went somewhere else, that would explain why it didn't happen while you were gone. You can get around this with chunk loaders. If you put one of these down in the area you want to keep active, everything in that chunk will keep moving and running. Now, if you spray these everywhere, your game might grind to a halt because the game has to do all the math constantly for these chunks. You want to use them sparingly--especially on servers!

tasks.longDescription: This guy will give you a big, centralized chunk loader that can work in a circular or square chunk area. This is particularly useful for large areas, but the lack of precision means you will probably keep some chunks loaded that you don't care about.

If you put that chunk loader in a crafting grid, you get 10 little ones. They call these "spot loaders." put one in each chunk in a place you can remember them. They're tiny so it's easy to forget where they are! This little guys let you be more precise. Honestly, you shouldn't normally need more than four of these in a huge base, plus one or two here and there for stuff like your moon base and other outposts in the multiverse.

quests.name: Eye Have Got An Adventure
quests.description: The Eye of Ender is a Vanilla Minecraft object added to try to get some kind of endering to the game. You can toss them with a right-click, and they'll fly out in the direction of the nearest underground stronghold. You can either make a bunch of these and just follow where they go until they crash right into the ground in front of you, or you can have two tops, toss them a couple hundred blocks apart, and use a linear intersection formal to triangulate where the stronghold is. I do that latter because I am a giant dork. A lot of people that play modded Minecraft have never even gone through all this trouble, but you at least need to make a for eyes of ender for *very advanced* crafting recipes in some mods.

tasks.longDescription: Combine an ender pearl with blaze powder. If blaze powder is scarce for you, look at recipes for creating it, and you'll find some machines can more efficiently crunch down blaze rods into powder.

quests.name: Return To Ender
quests.description: So Vanilla Minecraft has something like 3 strongholds within 1km of the Overworld spawn. If you start heading out in a direction, you can start sending out Eyes of Ender with a right click, and watching where they fly. Note the direction they go in, and check underneath them to see if they come back to the ground. Sometimes they just go *poof*. Again, you can do that linear intersection calculation from just two attempts like I do, but with modded Minecraft, vomiting these magical Eyes of Ender out is good enough. The goal is to get to the dimension called "The End." Yeah, it's because Minecraft was set up to end there. There's a dragon there that will trigger a Minecraft ending sequence (that is really strange). Don't worry, you can keep playing afterwards. Doing this doesn't have much value. The one perk is that the end stone in that dimension grows ender lilies ridiculously fast.

tasks.longDescription: So you get to the stronghold, and you plug in some of the portal bases with spare eyes of ender to activate the portal. Not so fast! This is a rough fight. Well, people do it in Vanilla. I did it wearing a pumpkin, which keeps the endermen from getting mad at me, and using an infinity bow. You can gear up just a little bit better than that and be in good shape. You need to shoot out the crystals on top of the towers because they restore the dragon's health. Then you can plink away on him. Enderium equipment will do this highly effectively. If you're on a server, somebody might have already done all this, so I can only check that you made it to The End at all.
While you're here, take some end stone with you. Ender lilies grow like my madness on them!

quests.name: An Ender-Game Weapon
quests.description: Thanks to the ExtraTiC mod, enderium can be forged into weapons! It is some serious stuff. Let's say, a manullyn cleaver does +14 damage. An enderium *rapier* can do the same . . . and much faster! An enderium cleaver can do +30 damage! It might be smarter to do the rapier because that skips armor, is enough to one-shot most stuff on a critical hit, and hits very quickly. Also: You want to tip your arrows and bolts with this stuff too.

tasks.longDescription: You know the deal. I can't check you made the specific weapon yadda yadda, but I can test you tried!

quests.name: Let's Mek A Teleporter!
quests.description: If you have made the digital miner, you are tooled to make this teleporter. It requires chunkloading too, and it is pretty resource intensive. However, if you have the stuff for it, then whatever. I'm not going to guide you through the tedium of making this like I did with the digital miner. I'm more focused on using it. You need a frame made of 9 teleporter frame blocks, and one teleporter core at the bottom. You make two of these, set up their frames and set them to the same channel. Poof! You have a teleporter.

tasks.longDescription: This requires a lot of the same advanced alloys and ingredients you had to make for the digital miner. Good luck! I'll be over here with a second set of teleporter parts so you can actually try it out!

quests.name: What's The Matter?
quests.description: Welcome to RFTools teleporters. Even if you decide to generally teleport yourself around through some other means for day-to-day stuff, you will need to make some of these for using the RFTools dimension building feature. What is that? Glad you asked! You can set up a device to create a parallel universe with all kinds of goofy differences and explore it to your hearts content. It could be a flat world, an empty sky world, an alien deathscape, floating islands, and oceans of liquid cocaine! Umm, regarding that last one, it seems to happen a lot if you install MineChem. It's not in this pack. :p

tasks.longDescription: You need a matter receiver and a matter transmitter. They both require the same basic block, which isn't too hard to make. Then you use 3 ender pearls with some extra materials to make each of the pair. Transmitters put the pearls on top, and receivers put the pearls on the bottom. Connect them to your power setup. They won't help you until you get a dialer. I'd also right-click each to give them unique names.
Make this dialer and power it too. Then you can set up teleportation from the matter transmitter to the matter receiver.

quests.name: Life Is A Beach
quests.description: When you opened up the dialing device, you probably saw this placed call "Beach Party." Eh? What is that? It's a great place! The water's warm! Okay, the *great* thing about is the mixture of beach and ocean biomes. You are looking for these little buildings out in the distance that give you extra dimlets that let you create more dimensions. Being able to paddle out to a bunch of them in a boat in flat ocean is a big deal!

quests.name: Spooky Action At A Distance
quests.description: Let's talk about quantum entanglement in AE2. You can create a remote portal to your ME network using a quantum entanglement chamber. Well, a "ring" would probably be a better definition after all is said and done. You will pipe a whole bunch of dense cable into it if you're trying to pass stuff back-and-forth through it. However, most of the time, a basic cable will suffice since all you want is to hit your terminal from some other place--like the moon.

tasks.longDescription: The matter condenser will consume items and start preparing a singularity from them. The value it places on each item is always the same: 1. So why not use the cheapest gunk you can make... cobblestone! However, this is going to take quite a bit of cobblestone...
No, really, lots of cobblestone. 256,000 of them, to be exact. You need to speed this show up! Use some speed upgrades in the transfer nodes.
You need a 64k storage module too. If you got to the advanced quest in the Applied Energistics 2 questline, then you can just queue up one of these babies and walk away.

The matter condenser will take care of that cobblestone. First, set it off of dispose mode into singularity mode. The matter ball mode is some fun you can have later; you can make little bullets and shoot stuff with them. But skip that. Insert the 64k cell in the TOP SLOT. DO THIS BY HAND. TAKE NO CHANCES OF IT ACCIDENTALLY DESTROYING THAT THING. Pipe in the cobblestone, and you should be able to see the cell fill up with "energy." You can hover over it to tell.
...You should have a singularity.

Now this is the strangest part. Dig yourself a little hole, drop the singularity in with an ender DUST, put some TNT next to it, and set it off. After the explosion, you should have two quantum entangled singularities. If you did the Boomtower quest, you can easily "borrow" some TNT for this.

quests.name: Entangled In ME Web.
quests.description: Getting those quantumly-entangled singularities was definitely the most tedious part of this process, but crafting the rings is going to eat up a lot of resources! You need 16 quantum rings and 2 quantum linking chambers. I will only ask for half of this and give you the other half. To set this up, you need to reserve some bandwidth on your ME network. I recommended evenly branching your network, and here you want to probably have a full branch dedicated to quantum entanglement. You probably want to keep most of your crafting happening at your home base, and ultimately just use a regular, 8-channel cable for the remote network. You can just punch in a terminal and do most of your stuff remotely.

tasks.longDescription: I'll just ask for enough to make one of the rings and give you enough to build the second ring! I'll throw in some yellow cable so you have something distinct to show at least one of your connections between the networks. Anyways, you build a 3x3 hollow ring out of the quantum rings, slap the chamber in the center, and pop an entangled singularity inside the chamber's GUI. Once you do that on the remote end--and supply it power--you will link! You probably need chunk loaders to keep both ends alive, by the way!

quests.name: Seeing From A New Dimension
quests.description: So maybe you want to go to some of these crazy dimensions. Very well. You need a dimension enscriber and a dimension builder. The enscriber configures the new dimension. The builder then creates it and powers it. Note that powering dimensions have different power costs, and they are more severe the more, well, over-powered the dimension is. Say, if you wanted to teleporting into diamond crystal land, then you're going to need a lot of juice!

tasks.longDescription: This is actually easier to make than the teleporters! BIG FAT NOTE: You want to complete the chunk loader quest to keep your power generation running when in another dimension. The stability of the dimension depends on getting a steady supply of power. If you don't have that, then the dimension WILL kill you!

quests.name: Consulting My Travel Staff
quests.description: You can lay out travel anchors all over your base, or between bases, or wherever you want, and use the staff of travel when standing on them to beam between them. Remote travel anchors will become more visible when you standing on one, so it is easy to point yourself the right way. Note that JourneyMap lets you set waypoints on its map that you can jump to at will, but this is a nice method to use for close-in, fine-tuned travel, like in a large base.

tasks.longDescription: The final step for making the staff isn't that bad. The soul binder is going to be a real pain, however. You need to start collecting heads, and specific ones! You may want to make yourself a Tinkers' Construct cleaver for this. Then you have to produce various alloys in an Ender IO alloy smelter. You have to make a crystal in that soul binder, and then it comes together. Is it worth it? Eventually. By the time your base is big enough to want one of these, you probably have the means to produce these things. Finally, you have the charge the thing. If you have a capacitor bank, then that's easy.
Making the anchors are straight-forward in comparison. But seriously, each one requires a diamond. I think that's dumb, so if you build one of these, I'll give you five more!

quests.name: Why Can't I Be Normal?
quests.description: Just about every mundane dimlet is craftable. So it's possible to make a dimension very similar to the Overworld without much work. Similarly, void dimensions and flat dimensions can be done from craftable dimlets. There's no point trying to explore for these particular ones.

tasks.longDescription: Use the default materials and liquids to get your regular stone/ore compositions and regular water/lava stuff. If you don't have these, your mundane dimension might end up being solid clay blocks with oceans of destabilized redstone. That's pretty cool, but it's probably not what you wanted!
You want to have the normal sky attributes if you want things to look right. Me? Sometimes I like to sneak in random planets and colors, but that's because I'm a nut.

The Default controller will approximate the Minecraft biome controller. It isn't going to necessarily produce all biomes, however. If you're making a dimension for your base, you might just want the Single controller. Just make sure to put a dimlet representing a biome in front of it. Otherwise, it will be some odd, random thing!

If you are creating a dimension for your base, you might decide that you don't want mobs. However, if you create a mob farm that's supposed to work in the dark, then you're in trouble. Is the default mob dimlet to keep things regular. Furthermore, if you omit this dimlet, that doesn't mean it won't just throw in mobs anyways. You need the "none" dimlet. You can't craft that. :p

You don't want a permanent effect in your dimension. I mean, regeneration might be fun, but that's a ton of extra RF, and you can't craft it! So you need the "none" effect dimlet. Features represent things like strongholds, fortresses, dungeons, and villages. They're nice to have, but if you are trying to control your dimension, you want to exclude them. Finally, the normal time dimlet makes sure everything grows at the normal rate. There's a fast time dimlet that'll make your crops go crazy, but it eats a ton of RF power. You also can't craft it!

Let's close off with two dimlets that are not normal, but are craftable. The flat world dimlet will give you a flat world like you'd get in the Minecraft editor. However, I think it will give you ground all the way up at Y=64, instead of putting you around Y=3. Also, there's a void world that lets you have a skyblock. Don't worry! You will start on the same old platform you get whenever you warp into a new dimension. I personally like to use the flat dimlet when making a world for exploring for more dimlets because it makes all those dimlet storage buildings stand out like sore thumbs.

quests.name: Applied Energistic's Pearl
quests.description: Applied Energistics likes to wrap ender pearls in fluix for all the stuff it uses for beaming stuff up. If you did the wireless quest, you have run into this guy already. If not, how convenient! I will give you some if you make me some!

tasks.longDescription: Hopefully, you're swimming in fluix at this point.

quests.name: Decoding The Multiverse
quests.description: By the time you got here, you have had to at least been to Beach Party. That's a great dimension for finding more dimlets. There are all these little shacks around that have unknown dimlets in them. We'll be going through what to do with them here.

tasks.longDescription: First, you need a supply of unknown dimlets. Go raid some shacks in Beach Party. That dimension is great due to the flatness and the bodies of water. With a boat, you can stroll around and very casually find out-of-place shacks that contain dimlets. You might find some as dungeon loot in the Overworld, but that will take too long.
A dimlet research will decode those dimlets into what they really are. Build this, power it, and feed it dimlets through its GUI.

Dimlets have different rarities. In any sufficiently-large pile of dimlets, you will get duplicates. With this scrambler, you can get another shot at them. It will take three known dimlets and produce two unknown dimlets. If you want to stretch your supply, one of the three can be a dimlet you can craft normally--but only one!

quests.name: A Very Spatial Place
quests.description: Applied Energistics is cool and all just for being able to store all your inventory in little disks. Sure, good job, AE2. However, that mod has gone completely off the deep end... or should I say, it has gone completely off the DEEP SPACE! You can actually set up frames in 3d space, and have it store all those objects in space onto disks. When you do this, you flip a switch, and poof, it all disappears onto the disk. You can then beam it back in and it reappears. Cool tricks you can do with this include: swapping parts of your base in and out of one giant frame, or even carving out a huge place in space, beaming yourself into it, and then building inside of there. Beware! You can't casually escape from storage! I mean... not without other mods!

tasks.longDescription: This box will hold the spatial drive the stores the contents of your frame. It is toggled with a button or a switch. It has inventory for just a single spatial drive, and it shifts it from an input side to an output side each time it is toggled. You have to move the drive back to re-activate the drive. That isn't a big deal. What really is nasty is how difficult it is to make this thing! It takes two ME drives, which is two engineering processors!

This task is practically just academic. I mean, you're just making the most basic of the spatial drives. The 2^3 drive is really only good for storing small areas. I normally only use it to beam up mob spawners in mod packs where there aren't other clever ways to do it. You light up the spawner so you can build in peace, and then build the pylons around it. You need three pylons vertically because the top and bottom vertical rows don't count towards the volume. Keep that in mind when calculating how many pylons you need. Eventually, you will be given a 128^3 drive containing a certain, mythical ship.

The frame is made out of these pylons. Generally, you want to go nuts on the pylons. You only need to frame out the three major axes of 3d space for it to figure out what you want to store, but the power loss of such a crude frame will probably kill your energy storage. By the way, you need AE2 energy cells to store the power for the spatial teleportation. The less efficient the rig, the more energy cells you need.
